content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Its awesome!

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Fun exercise. Great twist on the usual caesar cypher with a relatable trick to decide which shift is best.
Solved it in under 3 minutes using Ruby.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It's a fun exercise in working with ciphers and modulo, and it'll definitely be interesting to solve in shortest and reverse modes. Reverse mode may be a bit difficult, but it's doable based off of the name of the problem.
Very cool! That was fun, thanks :)
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!
Super exercise. Not for a 5-minutes exercise, but more 10 minutes though.

Is it possible to deactivate the mode 'Reverse', because I don't understand how you are suppose to know to use the caesar cypher with only the tests cases ? Unless you want the coders to use the title of the clash ?

I'm sorry if that's a dumb question, I new to evaluate the contributions.

Maybe you shall specify what to return if the decryption fails, with some associated test cases, like:
- AA BB CC (no word of three letters) => "Failed"
- ABC DEF ABC (no word of three letters having the pattern like THE) => "Failed"
- THE SGD THE SGD (no candidate winner in term of numbers) => "Failed"

I suggest to add a test where THE is indeed tested as a word and not just the pattern. Testing for the pattern passes every test at the moment and I don't think it's intended. 

For example, take ESP FTQFTQFTQ ESP:
-> The answer should be THE UIFUIFUIF THE
-> but this code gives SGD THETHETHE SGD

The code (ruby):

def caesar(msg, s)
  msg.tr((a = [*?A..?Z]).join, a.rotate(s).join)
end

txt = gets.chomp
txts = 26.times.map do |s|
  caesar(txt, s)
end

warn txts.max_by { |txt| txt.split.count("THE") }

# Pattern testing (Passes all tests)
ans = txts.max_by do |txt|
  txt.scan(/(?=THE)/).count
end
puts ans

Goal section
* Please give a very brief explanation of Caesar's cypher.

* Please change "the" to {{THE}} and remove the quotation marks (twice).

Thanks.
Thank you for your feedback. I have made the suggested changes.
Thank you for your suggestion. I have added a test case that requires testing THE as a complete word.

I don't think it is necessary for the fastest and the shortest modes since the constraint says explicitly that "[[plaintext]] is guaranteed to be unique". I also don't think it is necessary for the reverse mode either. The lack of the "failed" test cases is enough to communicate to the clashers that the solution is unique.

It's not a dumb question at all! Your perspective is valued even if you're a beginner.

Even though there are no direct indications that the texts are encrypted with Caesar's cypher, people will usually try to decrypt the text with Caesar's cypher first since it is perhaps the most well-known.

Nonetheless, it may be true that the reverse mode is too difficult for some people, especially those who have not heard of Caesar's cypher. I'll wait and see if there is more feedback regarding this matter.

I was thinking something similar. The fact it's expected to be solved with the word "THE" would be pretty easy to miss I think with a lot of solution ideas people might jump at, even if Task Failed Successfully does make it a bit clearer.
